key_insight: Combining a compact triangle mesh for smooth surface regions with anisotropic 3D Gaussians for detailed, view-dependent appearance yields photorealistic head avatars that are both memory- and compute-efficient enough for mobile rendering.
problem_solved: How to produce high-quality, photorealistic head avatars from multi-view images while keeping memory use and runtime low enough for real-time rendering on mobile devices.
method: Hybrid representation: use a lightweight triangle mesh to represent large smooth surfaces (e.g., skin) and anisotropic 3D Gaussians to capture fine details and view-dependent effects.
Fit the hybrid model from multi-view image captures to retain photorealism with far fewer primitives than purely point- or Gaussian-based models.
Optimize rendering and data layout for mobile — reducing memory footprint and enabling interactive frame rates with efficient blending of Gaussians and mesh rasterization.
impact: GPiCA enables deployment of high-fidelity avatars on resource-constrained devices, lowering the barrier for realistic virtual humans in mobile AR/VR, telepresence, and on-device personalization workflows.
visual_elements: Side-by-side comparison: standard mesh-only vs Gaussian-only vs GPiCA (hybrid) showing quality vs memory usage.
Pipeline diagram: multi-view capture → hybrid fitting → compact model → mobile renderer (frame ≈ realtime).
Illustration of hybrid primitive: mesh overlayed with anisotropic 3D Gaussian blobs showing how each covers different facial regions.
Bar chart: memory footprint and frame-rate (mobile) for GPiCA vs baseline methods.
paper_title: Gaussian Pixel Codec Avatars: A Hybrid Representation for Efficient Rendering
paper_authors: Divam Gupta, Anuj Pahuja, Nemanja Bartolovic, Tomas Simon, Forrest Iandola
